text:
- [Russell] Hello
everyone and welcome back
to our series on creating and uploading

an Amazon Workspaces Bring Your
Own License, or BYOL, Image.
So far, Dave and I have shown you

how to create an image using
Hyper-V and VMware Workstation.
And now, in Part 1 of this wrap up series,
we are going to see how we can install
the Amazon command line interface.
We're then gonna take a look at

how we configure the
command line interface
to make API calls into our AWS account.
And then we are gonna create

an Amazon Simple Storage
Service or Amazon S3 bucket.
Let's jump right in.
So the first place we're gonna start

is by downloading the Amazon
command line interface, or CLI.

So I have already
navigated to that website.

And over here on the
right-hand side of the page,
you can see we have the installs

for the different operating
systems that we support.
In my case, I am gonna choose Windows.
I'm gonna go ahead and run this install.

And for this install, I will
be selecting all the defaults.
And once we kick this off,
it will take just a moment to install.

So I will pause the video and
come back after the install.
Great, so we have that installed.
So now, I'm gonna open up a command prompt
and run an aws ?,

and we can see now that
we have different commands
for the AWS CLI.
Now that we have the AWS CLI installed,
we are gonna configure the AWS CLI

to be able to communicate
with our AWS account.

To do this, we are
gonna run aws configure.
I am gonna throw in an extra command here.
You could typically just run this
and this would set up the default profile,
but I am gonna run -- profile,
give this a name,

hit Enter, and here is
where we're going to enter
our AWS access keys.
Now, for default region,
I am going to use US East One

and for default output
format, I'm going to use JSON.
Now, there are other ways

to configure the command
line interface to interact

with your AWS account from
a security perspective.
For this demo, I chose the way
that was easiest for me.
For you, make sure you follow
your organization's best practice
by either using access keys
or potentially even using

the AWS Identity and
Access Management Center
to be able to authenticate
into your AWS account with the CLI.

Now, as a reminder,
there is no need to try

to quickly jot down the URLs
that I'm using for this.

I will link all those in
the description below.
The next thing we need to do

is to create an Amazon
Simple Storage Service
or Amazon S3 bucket.

To do so, we're gonna
log into the AWS account.
I am already logged into mine.
We are gonna navigate over to S3.

If it is not in your
recently visited items,

like it is for me, you can
simply go up to the Search,

type in S3 and it should
be the first option.
After we get into the S3 console,

over to the right-hand
side, we have Create Bucket.
We are going to select that.
Once we are in the Create Bucket Console,
we're gonna type a name for our bucket.
Typically, as I name my buckets,
I will add my initials with a date

because as a reminder
to create an S3 bucket,
it does have to be a globally unique name.
So I find at least adding in today's date

behind most of your names
will get you over that hurdle.

Now, here I am gonna
keep all the defaults.

I am gonna double check that
Block all public access is on,

and then I'm gonna scroll
down and click Create Bucket.
Now, as always, in creating S3 buckets,

please follow your
organization's best practices

for securing and limiting
access to that bucket.
For our demo, this will work just fine.
And there you have it for Part 1.
In this video, we installed

and configured Amazon's
command line interface

to be able to make API
calls into our AWS account.
We then created an Amazon S3 bucket

that we are gonna use in Part
2 of this wrap-up series.
As mentioned during the video,

there were some key links that
I used throughout the video.
I have put them up on the screen here,

but I will also link them in
the video description below.
Thank you all for watching

and be on the lookout for
Part 2 of a wrap-up series
where we're gonna copy that image
that we have in our local machine
to that S3 bucket we created,
take a look at some permissions required

to import that image
into Amazon Workspaces,

and then we're gonna
create an Amazon Workspaces
and an Amazon Workspaces Core BYOL Image.

I look forward to seeing
you all in that next video.
